message.content: We refer to developmental milestones charts for help. At 6 months old, the expected milestone is stranger anxiety, as the infant becomes more aware of unfamiliar faces and objects. Pretend play, sharing objects, and separation anxiety are expected at later stages of development.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on child development for help. At 6 months old, a child would be expected to develop stranger anxiety, which is the fear of unfamiliar people. The other options are expected to occur at later stages of development. Pretend play usually occurs at around 18 to 24 months of age. Separation anxiety usually occurs at around 9 to 18 months of age. Sharing interest with parents usually occurs at around 9 months of age.

We refer to developmental milestones for help. Stranger anxiety typically occurs around 6-9 months of age, while engaging in pretend play, showing objects to parents, and separation anxiety typically occur at later stages of development. Therefore, the expected milestone at this stage is stranger anxiety.

We refer to developmental milestones guidelines for help. At 6 months old, the additional milestone that would be expected is stranger anxiety, as the baby becomes cautious around unfamiliar people. Engaging in pretend play and sharing interest in an object with parents typically develop around 9-12 months, while separation anxiety may start at around 8 months.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. At 6 months of age, the expected milestone is stranger anxiety, which is a normal part of healthy development. Pretend play, separation anxiety, and sharing interest in an object are all milestones that occur later in development.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. At 6 months, the additional milestone that would be expected is stranger anxiety, where the child shows wariness or fear of unfamiliar people. Engaging in pretend play, separation anxiety, and sharing interest in objects would typically occur at later stages of development.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. At 6 months of age, the expected additional milestone is stranger anxiety, where the baby shows fear or wariness towards unfamiliar people. Pretend play and sharing interest with parents are not expected until later in development, while separation anxiety typically develops closer to 9 months of age.

We refer to reliable sources for child development milestones such as CDC or the American Academy of Pediatrics. At 6 months old, the expected additional milestone is stranger anxiety, which is the fear or wariness of unfamiliar people. Engaging in pretend play usually occurs around 18 to 24 months. Separation anxiety typically begins around 6 to 8 months but peaks around 14 to 18 months. Showing an object to parents to share her interest in that object typically occurs around 9 to 12 months.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. At 6 months of age, one of the expected milestones is to develop stranger anxiety, where infants become wary of strangers and prefer familiar people. Engaging in pretend play is not expected until around 18-24 months of age. Sharing an object with parents is expected at around 10-12 months of age, and separation anxiety typically begins around 9 months of age.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. At 6 months old, the most likely developmental milestone is stranger anxiety, where the baby becomes anxious around unfamiliar people. Engaging in pretend play is expected at around 18-24 months old, separation anxiety at around 8-12 months old, and showing an object to share interest at around 9-12 months old.
